The '''3M Company''' (originally the '''Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company''') is an American [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerate]] operating in the fields of industry, worker safety, and consumer goods.<ref name="vault">{{cite web |title=3M Company Profile |url=http://www.vault.com/company-profiles/computer-hardware/3m/company-overview |website=Vault.com |access-date=July 17, 2018}}</ref> Based in the [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]], suburb of [[Maplewood, Minnesota|Maplewood]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&client=safari&q=3M+CENTER,+BLDG.+maplewood+55144&ie=UTF-8&ei=t3oNUNDMAcjm2AXrxLUq&ved=0CEgQ_AUoAg |title=3M Center, Maplewood 55144 – Google Maps |publisher=Google Maps |access-date=July 14, 2013 }}</ref> the company produces over 60,000 products,<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.fool.com/investing/2018/10/24/premium-3m-company.aspx |title=Why 3M Company Finds It Hard to Keep Up With Investor Expectations |last=Chamaria |first=Neha |date=October 24, 2018 |website=The Motley Fool |access-date=October 10, 2019}}</ref> including [[adhesive]]s, [[abrasive]]s, [[Lamination|laminates]], [[passive fire protection]], [[personal protective equipment]], [[window film]]s, [[paint protection film]], electrical, electronic connecting, insulating materials, car-care products,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/Products/ProdServ/Dir/HealthCare/ |title=3M U.S.: Health Care |publisher=Solutions.3m.com |access-date=March 29, 2012}}</ref> [[electronic circuits]], and optical films.<ref name="3MWHO">{{cite web |url=http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/our/company/information/about-us/ |title=Who We Are – 3M US Company Information |publisher=Solutions.3m.com |access-date=July 14, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913044751/http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/our/company/information/about-us/ |archive-date=September 13, 2008 }}</ref> Among its best-known consumer brands are [[Scotch Tape]], [[Scotchguard]] surface protectants, [[Post-it]] notes, and [[Nexcare]] adhesive bandages. 3M’s stock ticker symbol is MMM and is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, Inc. (NYSE), the Chicago Stock Exchange, Inc., and the SIX Swiss Exchange.

3M made $35.4 billion in total sales in 2021 and ranked number 102 in the [[Fortune 500|''Fortune'' 500]] list of the largest United States corporations by total revenue.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Fortune 500: 3M |url=https://fortune.com/company/3m/fortune500/ |access-date=September 20, 2022|website=Fortune }}</ref> {{as of|2021}}, the company had approximately 95,000 employees and operations in more than 70 countries.<ref name="3M21">{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/ix?doc=/Archives/edgar/data/66740/000006674022000010/mmm-20211231.htm |title=3M Company 2021 Annual Report |date=February 9, 2021 |website=SEC.gov |publisher=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}}</ref> There are a few international subsidiaries, such as 3M India, 3M Japan, and 3M Canada.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/66740/000155837017000479/mmm-20161231ex215bcecc3.htm |title=3M Company and Consolidated Subsidiaries (Parent and Subsidiaries) as of December 31, 2016 |website=U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission}}</ref>

In June 2023, 3M reached a settlement to pay more than $10 billion to US public water systems to resolve claims over the company's contamination of water with [[Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances|PFASs]] (so-called forever chemicals).<ref name=":3">{{Cite news |date=2023-06-22 |title=3M pays $10.3bn to settle water pollution suit over 'forever chemicals' |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/jun/22/3m-settlement-municipal-water-systems-pfas-contamination |issn=0261-3077}}</ref> It has been revealed that the company knew of the health harms of PFAS in the 1990s, yet concealed these harms and continues to sell contaminated products.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Sakaguchi |first1=Sharon |last2=Lerner|first2= Haruka |date=2024-05-20 |title=Toxic Gaslighting: How 3M Executives Convinced a Scientist the Forever Chemicals She Found in Human Blood Were Safe |url=https://www.propublica.org/article/3m-forever-chemicals-pfas-pfos-inside-story |website=ProPublica |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Lerner |first=Sharon |date=2024-05-20 |title=How 3M Discovered, Then Concealed, the Dangers of Forever Chemicals |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2024/05/27/3m-forever-chemicals-pfas-pfos-toxic |magazine=The New Yorker |language=en-US |issn=0028-792X}}</ref>

== History ==
Five businessmen founded the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company as a mining venture in [[Two Harbors, Minnesota]], making their first sale on June 13, 1902.<ref name=3MCite /> The goal was to mine [[corundum]], a crystalline form of [[aluminium oxide]], which failed because the mine's mineral holdings were [[anorthosite]], a [[feldspar]] which had no commercial value. Co-founder John Dwan solicited funds in exchange for stock and Edgar Ober and [[Lucius Pond Ordway|Lucius Ordway]] took over the company in 1905. The company moved to [[Duluth, Minnesota|Duluth]] and began researching and producing [[sandpaper]] products. [[William L. McKnight]], later a key executive, joined the company in 1907, and [[Archibald Bush|A. G. Bush]] joined in 1909. 3M finally became financially stable in 1916 and was able to pay [[dividend]]s.<ref name="CPS">{{cite web |year=1999 |title=3M |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3427200011.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518022821/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-3427200011.html |archive-date=May 18, 2013 |access-date=October 4, 2012 |work=Company Profiles for Students |publisher=Gale}}</ref>

The company moved to [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]] in 1910, where it remained for 52 years before outgrowing the campus and moving to its current headquarters at 3M Center in [[Maplewood, Minnesota]], in 1962.<ref>{{cite web |title=900 Bush Avenue: The House that Research Built: Early Years in Saint Paul |url=http://saintpaulhistorical.com/items/show/354 |website=Saint Paul Historical |publisher=Historic Saint Paul |access-date=February 27, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170301005419/http://saintpaulhistorical.com/items/show/354 |archive-date=March 1, 2017 }}</ref>

[[File:3M Museum 2013.jpg|thumb|The [[John Dwan Office Building]], where 3M was founded, now a museum]]

In 1947, 3M began producing [[perfluorooctanoic acid]] (PFOA), an industrial [[surfactant]] and chemical [[feedstock]], by [[electrochemical fluorination]].<ref name=Prevedouros2006>{{cite journal |last1=Prevedouros |first1=Konstaninos |last2=Cousins |first2=Ian T. |last3=Buck |first3=Robert C. |last4=Korzeniowski |first4=Stephen H. |title=Sources, Fate and Transport of Perfluorocarboxylates |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |volume=40 |issue=1 |pages=32–44 |date=January 2006 |doi=10.1021/es0512475 |pmid=16433330 |bibcode=2006EnST...40...32P}}</ref> In 1951, [[DuPont (1802–2017)|DuPont]] purchased PFOA from then-Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company for use in the manufacturing of [[teflon]], a product that brought DuPont a billion-dollar-a-year profit by the 1990s.<ref name="NYT_jan_2016">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/10/magazine/the-lawyer-who-became-duponts-worst-nightmare.html?_r=0 |title=The Lawyer Who Became DuPont's Worst Nightmare |date=January 6, 2016 |access-date=January 8, 2016 |last=Rich |first=Nathaniel |work=The New York Times}}</ref> DuPont referred to PFOA as C8.<ref name=Emmett2006>{{cite journal |last1=Emmett |first1=Edward |last2=Shofer |first2=Frances |last3=Zhang |first3=Hong |last4=Freeman |first4=David |last5=Desai |first5=Chintan |last6=Shaw |first6=Leslie |title=Community exposure to Perfluorooctanoate: Relationships Between Serum Concentrations and Exposure Sources |journal=Journal of Occupational and Environmental Medicine |volume=48 |issue=8 |pages=759–70 |date=August 2006 |pmid=16902368 |pmc=3038253 |doi=10.1097/01.jom.0000232486.07658.74}}</ref>{{Anchor|3M Pharmaceuticals|Riker Laboratories}} The original formula for [[Scotchgard]], a water repellent applied to fabrics, was discovered accidentally in 1952 by 3M chemists [[Patsy Sherman]] and [[Samuel Smith (chemist)|Samuel Smith]]. Sales began in 1956, and in 1973 the two chemists received a [[patent]] for the formula.<ref>{{US patent|3574791}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-12-17 |title=Scotchgard vs Scotchguarding |url=https://stainprotect.ca/scotchgard-vs-scotchguarding/ |access-date=2023-06-01 |website=Stain Protection Services |language=en-US}}</ref>

In the late 1950s, 3M produced the first [[asthma inhaler]],<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38627878/inhalers_become_environmentally_friendly/ |title=Inhalers become environmentally friendly |date=February 3, 1998 |work=The StarPhoenix |agency=Canadian Press |location=Saskatoon, Saskatchewan |page=D3 |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> but the company did not enter the pharmaceutical industry until the mid-1960s with the acquisition of Riker Laboratories, moving it from California to Minnesota.<ref>{{Cite book |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KFM0t9Q8LZoC&pg=PA4 |title=Nimesulide: Actions and Uses |last=Rainsford |first=K. D. |publisher=Birkhäuser Verlag |year=2005 |isbn=978-3-7643-7068-8 |editor-last=Rainsford |editor-first=K. D. |location=Basel |pages=4 |chapter=The discovery, development and novel actions of nimesulide |via=Google Books (Preview)}}</ref> 3M retained the Riker Laboratories name for the subsidiary until at least 1985.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38631878/space_drug/ |title=Space Drug |last=Slovut |first=Gordon |date=November 19, 1985 |work=Minneapolis Star and Tribune |pages=[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38631975/space_drug_page1/ 1A], 11A |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In the mid-1990s, 3M Pharmaceuticals, as the division came to be called, produced the first [[Chlorofluorocarbon|CFC]]-free asthma inhaler in response to adoption of the [[Montreal Protocol]] by the United States.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38628640/3m_urges_closer_look_at_inhalers/ |title=3M urges closer look at inhalers |last=Staff |date=October 12, 1996 |work=Kenosha News |page=C6 |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38628834/airing_out_the_epa_3m_inhaler_scam/ |title=Airing out the EPA, 3M inhaler scam |last1=Anderson |first1=Jack |date=January 12, 1998 |work=The Daily Chronicle |last2=Moller |first2=Jan |location=DeKalb, Illinois |page=4 |type=Opinion |author-link=Jack Anderson (columnist) |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> In the 1980s and 1990s, the company spent fifteen years developing a [[topical cream]] delivery technology which led in 1997 to health authority approval and marketing of a [[symptomatic treatment]] for [[genital wart]]s, [[Imiquimod|Aldara]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38629415/3m_geta_approval_for_warts_treatment/ |title=3M gets approval for warts treatment |date=March 4, 1997 |work=La Crosse Tribune |agency=Associated Press |page=B3 |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-S4aCgAAQBAJ&pg=SL3-PA322 |title=Strategic Management: Theory & Cases: An Integrated Approach |last1=Hill |first1=Charles W. L. |last2=Jones |first2=Gareth R. |last3=Schilling |first3=Melissa A. |publisher=Cengage Learning |year=2015 |isbn=978-1-285-18448-7 |edition=11th |location=Stamford, Connecticut |page=C-322 |via=Google Books (Preview)}}</ref> 3M divested its pharmaceutical unit through three deals in 2006, netting more than {{US$|2 billion}}.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38630756/drug_units_to_fetch_3m_21billion/ |title=Drug units to fetch 3M $2.1 billion |date=November 10, 2006 |work=The Philadelphia Inquirer |agency=Associated Press |edition=City |page=D2 |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/38631400/greaceway_acquires_3m_branded_pharma/ |title=Graceway Inc. acquires 3M's branded pharmaceuticals in $875 million deal |date=November 10, 2006 |work=Johnson City Press |agency=NET News Service |page=7C |via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> At the time, 3M Pharmaceuticals comprised about 20% of 3M's healthcare business and employed just over a thousand people.<ref name=":0" />

By the 1970s, 3M developed a [[theatrical blood]] formula based on red colorfast [[microbead]]s suspended in a carrier liquid.<ref name="Theatre Crafts">{{cite book|title=Theatre Crafts, Volume 23, Issues 1-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YG8cAQAAIAAJ|date=1989|page=12|publisher=Rodale Press |access-date=September 15, 2020|quote="Schaefer Applied Technology of Norwood, Massachusetts, has put Nextel Brand Simulated Blood back on the market. This stage blood developed by 3M, is based on colorfast red microbeads suspended in a carrier liquid, and contains no dyes, detergents, or sugar syrup, and will not cause staining or damage to existing dyes."}}</ref> This stage blood was sold as Nextel Simulated Blood<ref name="Theatre Crafts" /><ref name="3M blood Tweet">{{cite tweet|replyto=CrypticPictures|user=3M|number=1134580753113726976|date=May 31, 2019|title=Hi there – Thank you for reaching out! Unfortunately, Nextel simulated blood has pulled a permanent vanishing act. We're sorry to disappoint; hope there's no bad blood between us|link=https://twitter.com/3M/status/1134580753113726976 |access-date=September 15, 2020}}</ref> and was used during the production of the 1978 film ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Savini|first=Tom|author-link=Tom Savini|date=1983|title=Grande Illusions: A Learn-By-Example Guide to the Art and Technique of Special Make-Up Effects from the Films of Tom Savini|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uQEnAQAAIAAJ|publisher=Imagine, Inc.|page=43|isbn=0-911137-00-9}}</ref> It has since been discontinued.<ref name="3M blood Tweet" />

In the late 1970s, 3M Mincom was involved in some of the first [[digital audio]] recordings to see commercial release when a prototype machine was brought to the [[Sound 80]] studios in [[Minneapolis]]. In 1979 3M introduced a digital audio recording system called "3M Digital Audio Mastering System".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mixonline.com/TECnology-Hall-of-Fame/1978-EM-Mastering/ |title=1978 3M Digital Audio Mastering System-Mix Inducts 3M Mastering System Into 2007 TECnology Hall of Fame |publisher=Mixonline.com |date=September 1, 2007 |access-date=March 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313125926/http://mixonline.com/TECnology-Hall-of-Fame/1978-EM-Mastering/ |archive-date=March 13, 2012 }}</ref>

3M launched "Press 'n Peel" a sticky [[bookmark]] page holder in stores in four cities in 1977, but the results were disappointing.<ref name="FT">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/f08e8a9a-fcd7-11df-ae2d-00144feab49a.html#axzz18hyDnyKX |title=First Person: 'We invented the Post-It Note' |first1=Art |last1=Fry |first2=Spencer |last2=Silver |access-date=December 20, 2010 |magazine=FT Magazine}}</ref><ref name="2ndchance">{{cite web |url=https://tv.yahoo.com/news/article/tv.accesshollywood.com/tv.accesshollywood.com-couple-who-lost-800000-foxs-million-dollar-money-drop-will-get-another-chance-play-cash |title=TV News Headlines – Yahoo TV |work=Yahoo TV}}</ref> A year later 3M instead issued free samples of it as a [[sticky note]] directly to consumers in [[Boise, Idaho]], with 95% of those who tried them indicating they would buy the product.<ref name="FT" /> The product was sold as "[[Post-It Note|Post-Its]]" in 1979 when the rollout introduction began,<ref name="nyt10">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/25/business/media/25show.html?_r=0 |title=Right on the $800,000 Question, They Lost Anyway |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=September 21, 2015 |date=December 24, 2010 |last1=Stelter |first1=Brian}}</ref> and was sold across the United States<ref name="nyt10" /> from April 6, 1980.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Szycher|first=Michael|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oDduDwAAQBAJ&q=%22April+6%2C+1980%22+%22Post-it%22&pg=PT176|title=Szycher's Practical Handbook of Entrepreneurship and Innovation|date=September 4, 2018|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=978-1-351-73636-7 }}</ref> The following year they were launched in Canada and Europe.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.3m.com/us/office/postit/pastpresent/history_tl.html |title=The Evolution of the Post-it Note |access-date=February 13, 2010 |publisher=3M}}</ref>

In 1980, the company acquired [[Comtal]], a manufacturer of [[digital image processing|digital image processors]].<ref>{{cite journal | last=Barnfather | first=Maurice | date=March 1, 1982 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UvodAQAAMAAJ | title=Can 3M Find Happiness in the 1980s? | work=Forbes <!--| volume=129 | issue=?--> | pages=113–116 | via=Google Books}}</ref>

===21st century===
On April 8, 2002, 3M's 100th anniversary, the company changed its legal name to "3M Company".<ref name="3M timeline">{{cite web|url=https://www.3m.com/3M/en_US/company-us/about-3m/history/timeline/|title=Timeline of 3M History|website=3M |access-date=March 20, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://money.cnn.com/2002/04/04/news/companies/mmm/index.htm|title=3M raises 1Q estimates|website=CNN Money |access-date=March 20, 2020|date=April 4, 2002 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020612131519/https://money.cnn.com/2002/04/04/news/companies/mmm/index.htm |archive-date=June 12, 2002|url-status=live}}</ref> On September 8, 2008, 3M announced an agreement to acquire Meguiar's, a car-care products company that was family-owned for over a century.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://meguiarsonline.com/forums/showthread.php?t=27025 |title=3M to Acquire Meguiar's, Inc |website=Meguiar's Online |date=September 8, 2008 |access-date=March 29, 2012}}</ref> In August 2010, 3M acquired [[Cogent Systems]] for $943 million,<ref>{{cite news |last=Sayer |first=Peter |title=3M Offers $943M for Biometric Security Vendor Cogent Systems |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/204400/article.html |access-date=February 16, 2013 |newspaper=[[PC World]] |date=August 30, 2010}}</ref> and on October 13, 2010, 3M completed acquisition of Arizant Inc.<ref name="htanna">{{cite web |url=http://news.3m.com/press-release/company/3m-completes-acquisition-arizant-inc |title=3M Completes Acquisition of Arizant Inc. |publisher=3M |access-date=October 15, 2010 |archive-date=March 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140309055532/http://news.3m.com/press-release/company/3m-completes-acquisition-arizant-inc }}</ref> In December 2011, 3M completed the acquisition of the Winterthur Technology Group, a bonded abrasives company.

As of 2012, 3M was one of the 30 companies included in the [[Dow Jones Industrial Average]], added on August 9, 1976, and was 97 on the 2011 [[Fortune 500]] list.<ref>{{cite news |title=Fortune 500 2011: Fortune 1,000 Companies 1–100 |url=https://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune500/2011/full_list/ |work=Fortune Magazine |access-date=March 20, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102224441/https://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune500/2011/full_list/ |archive-date=January 2, 2012 |url-status=live}}</ref> On January 3, 2012, it was announced that the Office and Consumer Products Division of [[Avery Dennison]] was being bought by 3M for $550 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2012/01/03/3m-avery-dennison-deal/ |title=3M buys office supply unit of Avery Dennison for $550M |website=Minnesota Public Radio News |date=January 3, 2012 |access-date=March 29, 2012}}</ref> The transaction was canceled by 3M in September 2012 amid antitrust concerns.<ref>{{cite news |last=Robinson |first=Will |title=3M Drops Avery Dennison Unit Buyout Amid Antitrust Worry |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-09-04/3m-drops-avery-dennison-unit-buyout-amid-antitrust-worry |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120908062750/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-09-04/3m-drops-avery-dennison-unit-buyout-amid-antitrust-worry |url-status=dead |archive-date=September 8, 2012 |access-date=April 14, 2014 |newspaper=Bloomberg News |date=September 5, 2012}}</ref>

In May 2013, 3M sold [[Scientific Anglers]] and Ross Reels to [[Orvis]]. Ross Reels had been acquired by 3M in 2010.<ref name="Anderson">{{cite news |last1=Anderson |first1=Dennis |title=3M to sell two fly-fishing businesses to Orvis |location=Minneapolis |newspaper=StarTribune |date=May 2, 2013}}</ref>

In March 2017, 3M purchased Johnson Controls International Plc's safety gear business, Scott Safety, for $2 billion.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-johnsoncontrols-scottsafety-3m-idUSKBN16N1M8 |title=3M to buy Johnson Controls' safety gear business for $2 billion |date=March 16, 2017 |work=Reuters |access-date=March 16, 2017}}</ref>

In 2017, 3M had net sales for the year of $31.657 billion, up from $30.109 billion the year before.<ref name="Yahoo Finance 3M">{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/why-3m-company-mmm-down-084108646.html |title=Why Is 3M Company (MMM) Down 6.1% Since its Last Earnings Report? |date=February 26, 2018 |website=Yahoo}}</ref> In 2018, it was reported that the company would pay $850 million to end the Minnesota water pollution case concerning [[Perfluorinated compound|perfluorochemicals]].<ref name="CNN on Pollution">{{cite web |url=https://money.cnn.com/2018/02/20/news/companies/3m-minnesota-environmental-settlement/index.html |title=3M will pay $850 million in Minnesota to end water pollution case |date=February 21, 2018 |website=[[CNN]]}}</ref>

On May 25, 2018, [[Michael F. Roman]] was appointed CEO by the board of directors.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://marketexclusive.com/3m-company-nysemmm-files-an-8-k-departure-of-directors-or-certain-officers-election-of-directors-appointment-of-certain-officers-compensatory-arrangements-of-certain-officers-3/2018/05/ |title=3M COMPANY (NYSE:MMM) Files An 8-K Departure of Directors or Certain Officers; Election of Directors; Appointment of Certain Officers; Compensatory Arrangements of Certain Officers |website=Market Exclusive.com |date=May 25, 2018 |access-date=May 25, 2018}}</ref> On December 19, 2018, 3M announced it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the technology business of M*Modal, for a total enterprise value of $1.0 billion.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20181219005317/en/3M-Acquire-M*Modal%E2%80%99s-Technology-Business |title=3M to Acquire M*Modal's Technology Business |date=December 19, 2018 |website=businesswire.com |access-date=October 28, 2019}}</ref>

== Environmental record ==
[[File:Target Plaza South.jpg|thumb|upright|The Target Light System, built by 3M at [[Target Corporation|Target]] headquarters in [[Minneapolis]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/twincities/stories/2003/04/14/focus2.html?page=1 |title=Target Lights Create Evolving Minneapolis Landmark |work=Minneapolis/St. Paul Business Journal |date=April 11, 2003}}</ref>]]

3M's Pollution Prevention Pays (3P) program was established in 1975. The program initially focused on pollution reduction at the plant level and was expanded to promote recycling and reduce waste across all divisions in 1989. By the early 1990s, approximately 2,500 3P projects decreased the company's total global pollutant generation by 50 percent and saved 3M $500–600 million by eliminating the production of waste requiring subsequent treatment.<ref>{{cite news |last=Holusha |first=John |title=Hutchinson No Longer Holds Its Nose |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/03/business/hutchinson-no-longer-holds-its-nose.html |access-date=January 8, 2020 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 3, 1991}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Oster |first1=Patrick |title=Going 'Green' and the Bottom Line |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/1993/01/23/going-green-and-the-bottom-line/f78654e2-270c-4138-9214-d060e012baa1/ |access-date=January 8, 2020 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=January 23, 1993 }}</ref>

In 1983, the [[Oakdale Dump]] in [[Oakdale, Minnesota]], was listed as an EPA [[Superfund]] site after significant [[groundwater]] and [[soil]] [[contamination]] by [[Volatile organic compound|VOCs]] and [[heavy metals]] was uncovered.<ref>{{cite web |title=Superfund Site: Oakdale Dump Oakdale, MN |url=https://cumulis.epa.gov/supercpad/SiteProfiles/index.cfm?fuseaction=second.Contams&id=0503840 |website=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency |access-date=July 18, 2017 }}</ref> The Oakdale Dump was a 3M dumping site utilized through the 1940s and 1950s.

During the 1990s and 2000s, 3M reduced releases of toxic pollutants by 99 percent and greenhouse gas emissions by 72 percent. As of 2012, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) had awarded 3M with the [[Energy Star]] Award each year that it has been presented.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Winston |first1=Andrew |title=3M's Sustainability Innovation Machine |journal=[[Harvard Business Review]] |date=May 15, 2012 |url=https://hbr.org/2012/05/3ms-sustainability-innovation.html |access-date=January 8, 2020}}</ref>

=== "Forever chemicals" water pollution ===
In 1999, the EPA began investigating [[Perfluorinated compound|perfluorinated chemicals]] after receiving data on the global distribution and toxicity of [[perfluorooctanesulfonic acid]] (PFOS).<ref>{{cite web |first=Aziz |last=Ullah |url=https://www.restorationindustry.org/buyersguide/FlurochemicalsOct06.pdf |title=The Fluorochemical Dilemma: What the PFOS/PFOA Fuss Is All About |work=Cleaning & Restoration |date=October 2006 |access-date=October 25, 2008}}</ref> These materials are part of a broad group of perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances often referred to as [[Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances|PFAS]], each of which has different chemical properties.<ref>{{cite web |title=What are PFCs and How Do They Relate to Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFASs)? |url=https://www.epa.gov/pfas/what-are-pfcs-and-how-do-they-relate-and-polyfluoroalkyl-substances-pfass |website=[[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] |access-date=July 13, 2020}}</ref> 3M, the former primary producer of PFOS from the U.S., announced the phase-out of PFOS, [[perfluorooctanoic acid]], and PFOS-related product production in May 2000.<ref name="3M08">{{cite web |website=3M |url=http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/PFOS/PFOA/Information/Action/ |title=PFOS-PFOA Information: What is 3M Doing? |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922004724/http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/PFOS/PFOA/Information/Action/ |archive-date=September 22, 2008 |access-date=October 25, 2008}}</ref><ref name="Fellner">{{cite news |last1=Fellner |first1=Carrie |title=Toxic Secrets: Professor 'bragged about burying bad science' on 3M chemicals |url=https://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/health-and-wellness/toxic-secrets-professor-bragged-about-burying-bad-science-on-3m-chemicals-20180615-p4zlsc.html |access-date=June 25, 2018 |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=June 16, 2018}}</ref> Perfluorinated compounds produced by 3M have been used in non-stick cookware, stain-resistant fabrics, and other products.

The [[Cottage Grove, Minnesota|Cottage Grove]] facility manufactured PFAS from the 1940s to 2002.<ref name="health.state.mn.us">{{cite web |url=http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/eh/hazardous/sites/washington/3Mcottagegrove.html |title=Perfluorochemicals and the 3M Cottage Grove Facility |website=Minnesota Dept. of Health |date=December 15, 2011 |access-date=March 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429112519/http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/eh/hazardous/sites/washington/3Mcottagegrove.html |archive-date=April 29, 2012 }}</ref> In response to PFAS contamination of the [[Mississippi River]] and surrounding area, 3M stated the area will be "cleaned through a combination of [[groundwater]] pump-out wells and soil sediment excavation". The restoration plan was based on an analysis of the company property and surrounding lands.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/eh/hazardous/sites/washington/3mcg0205.pdf |title=Health Consultation: 3M Chemolite: Perfluorochemicals Releases at the 3M – Cottage Grove Facility Minnesota Department of Health, Jan. 2005 |access-date=March 29, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808161547/http://www.health.state.mn.us/divs/eh/hazardous/sites/washington/3mcg0205.pdf |archive-date=August 8, 2016 }}</ref> The on-site water treatment facility that handled the plant's post-production water was not capable of removing PFAS, which were released into the nearby Mississippi River.<ref name="health.state.mn.us" /> The clean-up cost estimate, which included a granular activated carbon system to remove PFAS from the ground water was $50 to $56 million,<ref>{{cite web |title=Perfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) Sites in Minnesota |url=https://www.health.state.mn.us/communities/environment/hazardous/topics/sites.html#CG |publisher=[[Minnesota Department of Health]]}}</ref> funded from a $147 million environmental reserve set aside in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.startribune.com/state-s-lawsuit-against-3m-over-pfcs-at-crossroads/239710011/ |title=State's lawsuit against 3M over PFCs at crossroads |work=StarTribune |location=Minneapolis |date=January 13, 2014 |access-date=May 20, 2015 }}</ref>

In 2008, 3M created the Renewable Energy Division within 3M's Industrial and Transportation Business to focus on Energy Generation and Energy Management.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://solutions.3m.com/wps/portal/3M/en_US/global/sustainability/ |title=Sustainability at 3M |website=3M |access-date=March 29, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2009/02/3m-forms-renewable-energy-division-54663 |title=3M Forms Renewable Energy Division |website=Renewable Energy World.com |access-date=March 29, 2012 |date=February 4, 2009 }}</ref>

In late 2010, the state of Minnesota sued 3M for {{dollarsign|US}}5 billion in punitive damages, claiming they released [[Perfluorinated compound|PFCs]]—classified a toxic chemical by the EPA—into local waterways.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6BT31L20101230 |work=Reuters |title=Minnesota sues 3M over pollution claims |date=December 30, 2010}}</ref> A settlement for $850 million was reached in February 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2018/02/20/3m-pfc-groundwater-pollution-trial-announcement |title=Minnesota settles water pollution suit against 3M for $850 million |last1=Dunbar |first1=Elzabeth |date=February 20, 2018 |access-date=February 20, 2018 |website=MPR News |last2=Marohn |first2=Kirsti}}</ref><ref name="Fellner" /><ref name="Fellner1">{{cite news |last1=Fellner |first1=Carrie |title=Toxic Secrets: The town that 3M built – where kids are dying of cancer |url=https://www.smh.com.au/world/north-america/toxic-secrets-the-town-that-3m-built-where-kids-are-dying-of-cancer-20180613-p4zl83.html |access-date=June 25, 2018 |work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=June 15, 2018}}</ref> In 2019, 3M, along with the [[Chemours]] Company and [[DuPont]], appeared before lawmakers to deny responsibility, with company Senior VP of Corporate Affairs Denise Rutherford arguing that the chemicals pose no human health threats at current levels and that there were no victims.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2019/sep/11/pfas-toxic-forever-chemicals-hearing-3m-dupont-chemours |title=Companies deny responsibility for toxic 'forever chemicals' contamination |last=Holden |first=Emily |date=September 11, 2019 |work=The Guardian |access-date=October 10, 2019 |issn=0261-3077 }}</ref>

In 2021, research had determined that 3M's [[Zwijndrecht, Belgium|Zwijndrecht (Belgium)]] factory caused PFOS pollution that may be contaminating agricultural products within a 15 kilometer radius of the plant which includes [[Antwerp]].<ref>{{cite web|last=van den Buijs|first=Dennis|title=Schepen leefmilieu Zwijndrecht: "Verbod op het eten van eieren van eigen kippen staat zo goed als vast" |trans-title=Alderman for the environment of Zwijndrecht: "Ban on eating eggs from our own chickens is almost fixed" |language=nl |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2021/06/10/verbod-op-komst-op-het-eten-van-eieren-van-eigen-kippen-in-zwijn/ |access-date=June 10, 2021|website=[[VRT (broadcaster)|VRT]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New guidelines to mitigate health risks for people living near Antwerp factory |url=https://www.brusselstimes.com/news/belgium-all-news/173926/new-guidelines-to-mitigate-health-risks-for-people-living-near-antwerp-3m-factory/|website=[[The Brussels Times]] |date=June 15, 2021}}</ref> The [[Flemish Government]] has paid 63 million euros for cleanup costs so far with 3M contributing 75,000 euros.<ref>{{cite web|last=van den Buijs |first=Dennis |url=https://www.vrt.be/vrtnws/nl/2021/06/15/pfos-activist-thomas-goorden-3m-chanteerde-vlaamse-regering-met/ |website=[[VRT (broadcaster)|VRT]]|title=Burgeractivist in PFOS-dossier Thomas Goorden: "3M chanteerde Vlaamse regering met vertrek in 2017" |trans-title=Civilian activist in PFOS file Thomas Goorden: "3M blackmailed the Flemish government with departure in 2017" |language=nl|date=June 15, 2021}}</ref> The Flemish Government issued measures advising against the consumption of, for example, home-grown eggs within a radius of 5 kilometers.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Lantis mag 3M niet meer aansprakelijk stellen voor PFOS-vervuiling |url=https://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20210614_98037939 |access-date=2022-10-24 |website=De Standaard |language=nl-BE}}</ref>

== Earplug controversy ==
The Combat Arms Earplugs, Version 2 (CAEv2), was developed by Aearo Technologies for U.S. military and civilian use. The CAEv2  was a double ended earplug that 3M claimed would offer users different levels of protection.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fox13news.com/news/veterans-sue-3m-claim-faulty-ear-plugs-caused-hearing-damage|title=Veterans sue 3M, claim faulty ear plugs caused hearing damage|last=Hinds|first=Haley|date=October 29, 2019|website=FOX 13 News |access-date=April 20, 2020}}</ref> Between 2003 and 2015, these earplugs were standard issue to members of the U.S. military.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://about.bgov.com/news/vets-tormented-by-hearing-loss-face-3m-in-earplug-mass-lawsuit/|title=Vets Tormented by Hearing Loss Face 3M in Earplug Mass Lawsuit|website=Bloomberg Government |access-date=April 20, 2020}}</ref> 3M acquired Aearo Technologies in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.3m.com/press-release/company/3m-acquire-aearo-technologies-inc-global-leader-personal-protection-equipment|title=3M to Acquire Aearo Technologies Inc., Global Leader in Personal Protection Equipment|website=3M News {{!}} United States |access-date=April 20, 2020 |archive-date=May 19, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519232526/http://news.3m.com/press-release/company/3m-acquire-aearo-technologies-inc-global-leader-personal-protection-equipment }}</ref>

In May 2016, Moldex-Metric, Inc., a 3M competitor, filed a [[Whistleblowing|whistleblower]] complaint against 3M under the [[False Claims Act]]. Moldex-Metric claimed that 3M made false claims to the U.S. government about the safety of its earplugs and that it knew the earplugs had an inherently defective design.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stripes.com/news/contractor-settles-for-9-1-million-after-providing-defective-earplugs-for-servicemembers-1.540137|title=Contractor settles for $9.1 million after providing defective earplugs for servicemembers|website=Stars and Stripes|access-date=April 20, 2020|archive-date=July 24, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200724194257/https://www.stripes.com/news/contractor-settles-for-9-1-million-after-providing-defective-earplugs-for-servicemembers-1.540137|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2018, 3M agreed to pay $9.1 million to the U.S. government to resolve the allegations, without admitting liability.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/3m-company-agrees-pay-91-million-resolve-allegations-it-supplied-united-states-defective-dual|title=3M Company Agrees to Pay $9.1 Million to Resolve Allegations That it Supplied the United States With Defective Dual-Ended Combat Arms Earplugs|date=July 26, 2018|website=Justice.gov |access-date=April 20, 2020}}</ref>

Since 2018, more than 140,000 former users of the earplugs (primarily U.S. military veterans) have filed suit against 3M claiming they suffer from hearing loss, tinnitus, and other damage as a consequence of the defective design.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pnj.com/story/news/2020/04/07/3-m-lawsuit-military-faulty-earplugs-veterans-pensacola-judge-hearing-damage/2955585001/|title=Pensacola judge weighing lawsuit claiming 3M earplugs damaged veterans' hearing|last=Robinson|first=Kevin|website=Pensacola News Journal |access-date=April 20, 2020}}</ref>

Internal emails showed that 3M officials boasted about charging $7.63 per piece for the earplugs which cost 85 cents to produce. The company's official response indicated that the cost to the government includes R&D costs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|date=2020|title=3M billed government $7.63 for 85-cent earplugs. It now has $1 billion COVID contract|work=McClatchy|url=https://www.mcclatchydc.com/news/coronavirus/article242868916.html }}</ref>

3M settled close to 260,000 lawsuits in August 2023 by agreeing to pay $6 billion to current and former U.S. military members who were affected.<ref>{{cite news |last=Pierson |first=Brendan |date=August 28, 2023 |title=3M agrees to pay $6 bln to settle lawsuits over US military earplugs |url=https://www.reuters.com/legal/3m-board-vote-multibillion-dollar-settlement-military-earplug-litigation-2023-08-28/ |work=Reuters}}</ref>

== N95 respirators and the COVID-19 pandemic ==
The [[N95 respirator]] mask was developed by 3M and approved in 1972.<ref name=":62">{{Cite web|last=Wilson|first=Mark|date=March 24, 2020|title=The untold origin story of the N95 mask|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/90479846/the-untold-origin-story-of-the-n95-mask |access-date=March 27, 2020|website=Fast Company }}</ref> Due to its ability to filter viral particulates, its use was recommended during the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] but supply soon became short.<ref name=":62" /> Much of the company's supply had already been sold prior to the outbreak.<ref>{{cite news|date=March 16, 2020|title=The World Needs Masks. China Makes Them — But Has Been Hoarding Them|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/13/business/masks-china-coronavirus.html}}</ref>

The shortages led to the U.S. government asking 3M to stop exporting US-made N95 respirator masks to Canada and to Latin American countries,<ref>{{Cite news|date=April 3, 2020|title=Trump 'Wants to Stop Mask Exports to Canada' |work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-52161032 |access-date=April 4, 2020}}</ref> and President [[Donald Trump]] invoked the [[Defense Production Act]] to require 3M to prioritize orders from the federal government.<ref name=":2">{{cite news|date=April 6, 2020|title=3M will import masks from China for U.S. to resolve dispute with the Trump administration|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/04/06/3m-will-import-masks-china-us-resolve-dispute-with-trump-administration/}}</ref> The dispute was resolved when 3M agreed to import more respirators, mostly from its factories in China.<ref name=":2" />

3M later struck a [[Canadian dollar|CA$]]70M deal with the federal government of Canada and the [[Ontario]] provincial government to produce N95 masks at their plant in [[Brockville, Ontario|Brockville]], Ontario.<ref>{{Cite web |date=August 20, 2020 |title=3M to make critical N95 masks at Brockville, Ont., plant |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/n95-ford-trudeau-ppe-covid19-brockville-1.5693766 |access-date=August 25, 2020 |website=CBC News }}</ref>
